facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1953 before Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1953, Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 14, 1948 of the Chief Court of Audh, Lucknow in Second Appeal No. 365 of 1945 arising out of the decree dated May 30, 1945 of the Court of District Judge, Sitapur in Appeal No. 4 of 1945 against the decree dated November 25, 1944 of the Court of Additional Civil Judge, Sitapur in Regular Civil Suit No. 14 of 1944.

facts.text: Chief Court of Oudh judgment and decree dated July 14, 1948 in Second Appeal No. 365 of 1945

facts.text: District Judge Sitapur decree dated May 30, 1945 in Appeal No. 4 of 1945 affirmed trial court

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the decree dated May 30, 1945 of the Court of District Judge, Sitapur in Appeal No. 4 of 1945 against the decree dated November 25, 1944 of the Court of Additional Civil Judge, Sitapur in Regular Civil Suit No. 14 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: against the decree dated November 25, 1944 of the Court of Additional Civil Judge, Sitapur in Regular Civil Suit No. 14 of 1944. D. Mathur, for the appellant. Jagdish, Chandra, for respondent No. 1. 1956. October 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in the village of Bhadesia in the District of Sitapur is a private temple or a public one in which all the Hindus are entitled to worship.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Venkatarama Ayyar J. on October 4, 1956

anchor.surface_text: 1956. October 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in the village of Bhadesia in the District of Sitapur is a private temple or a public one in which all the Hindus are entitled to worship.

facts.text: Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in village Bhadesia, District Sitapur

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in the village of Bhadesia in the District of Sitapur is a private temple or a public one in which all the Hindus are entitled to worship.

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam constructed Thakurdwara during 1914-1916 and installed idol of Shri Radhakrishnaji

anchor.surface_text: One Sheo Ghulam, a pious Hindu and a resident of the said village, had the Thakurdwara constructed during the years 1914-1916, and the idol of Shri Radhakrishnaji ceremoniously installed therein.

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam managed temple till death in 1928 without issue

anchor.surface_text: He was himself in management of the temple and its affairs till 1928 when he died without any issue.

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam executed will on March 6, 1919 bequeathing all lands to Thakur

anchor.surface_text: On March 6, 1919, he had executed a will whereby he bequeathed all his lands to the Thakur.

facts.text: Sheo Ghulam had two wives: Ram Kuar predeceased, Raj Kuar managed as Mutawalli till 1933

anchor.surface_text: The testator had two wives one of whom Ram Kuar, had predeceased him and the surviving widow, Raj Kuar, succeeded him as Mutawalli in terms of the will and was in management. till her death in 1933.

facts.text: First defendant, nephew of Sheo Ghulam, took possession as manager per will after Raj Kuar's death

anchor.surface_text: Then the first defendant who is the nephew of Sheo Ghulam, got into possession of the properties as manager of the endowment in accordance with the provisions of the will.

facts.text: Appellant is distant agnate of Sheo Ghulam

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a distant agnate of Sheo Ghulam,

facts.text: Appellant alleged mismanagement by first defendant and denial of public rights, applied to District Court Sitapur under Religious Endowments Act XIV 1920, refused as private

anchor.surface_text: and on the allegation that the first defendant had been mismanaging the temple and denying the rights of the public therein, he moved the District Court of Sitapur for relief under the Religious and Charitable Endowments Act XIV of 1920, but the court declined to interfere on the ground that the endowment was private.

facts.text: Application to Advocate-General for sanction under s92 CPC refused as private endowment

anchor.surface_text: An application to the Advocate-General for sanction to institute a suit under section92 of the Code of Civil Procedure was also refused for the same reason.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit for declaration that Thakurdwara is public temple

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed the suit, out of which the present appeal arises, for a declaration that the Thakurdwara is a public temple in which all the Hindus have a right to worship.

facts.text: First defendant contested suit claiming Thakurdwara and idols private, no public right

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant contested the suit, and claimed that the Thakurdwara and the idols were private, and that the general public had no right to make any interference.

facts.text: Lower courts held Thakurdwara private temple, dismissed suit

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Civil Judge, Sitapur, who tried the suit was of the opinion that the Thakurdwara had been built by Sheo Ghulam for worship by his family, and that it was a private temple. He accordingly dismissed the suit. This judgment was affirmed on appeal by the District Judge, Sitapur, whose decision again was affirmed by the Chief Court of Oudh in second appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Thakurdwara is public temple

anchor.surface_text: Having considered all the aspects, we are of opinion that the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

facts.text: Formal dedication admitted by parties

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it was admitted that there was a formal dedication and the controversy is only as to the scope of- the dedication,

facts.text: Public worshipped in temple freely without interference

anchor.surface_text: The witnesses examined on his behalf deposed that the villagers were worshipping in the temple freely and without any interference,

facts.text: No temple in village before Thakurdwara built

anchor.surface_text: and indeed, it was even stated that the Thakurdwara was built by Sheo Ghulam at the instance of the villagers, as there was no temple in the village.

facts.text: Will Exhibit A-1 dedicates properties to Sri Radhakrishnan, wives as Mutawallis

anchor.surface_text: Clause I of Exhibit A-1 provides that after the death of the testator in the absence of male issue, the entire immovable property given below existing at present or which may come into being hereafter shall stand endowed in the name of Sri Radhakrisbnan, and mutation of names shall be effected in favour of Sri Radhakrishnan in the Government papers and my wives Mst. Raj Kuer and Mst. Ram kuer shall be the Muta- wallis of the waqf.

facts.text: Committee of management includes two non-relations of different caste

anchor.surface_text: Clause 2 appoints a committee of four persons to look after the , management of the temple and its properties, and of these, two are no relations of the testator and belong to a different caste.

facts.text: Installation ceremonies performed with great solemnity including Prathista

anchor.surface_text: P. W. 10, who officiated as Acharya at the function has deposed that it lasted for seven days, and that all the ceremonies commencing with Kalasa Puja and ending with Sthapana or Prathista were duly performed

facts.text: Thakurdwara built on separate building on vacant site, not in residential quarters

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, there is the fact that the idol was installed no within the precincts of residential quarters but in. a separate building constructed for that very purpose on a vacant site.

holdings.text: The Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

anchor.surface_text: Having considered all the aspects, we are of opinion that the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test (will, public user, ceremonies, other facts) to facts; intention for public beneficiaries; rejected lower courts.

holdings.text: The question whether the Thakurdwara is a public endowment or a private one is one of mixed law and fact, open to consideration in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision in this appeal whether the Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji at Bhadesia is a public endowment or a private one is one of mixed law and fact. In Lakshmidhar Misra v. Rangalal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Findings of fact binding but legal conclusion on dedication reviewable per Privy Council precedent.

holdings.text: The intention of the founder was that the general public have the right of worship at the shrine.

anchor.surface_text: The cardinal point to be decided is whether it was the intention of the founder that specified individuals are to have the right of worship at the shrine, or the general public or any specified portion thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Determined from will provisions (no issue, committee with strangers, perpetuity), user, ceremonies showing public dedication.

holdings.text: The will read as a whole indubitably reveals an intention to dedicate the Thakurdwara to the public and not merely to the members of his family.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to endorse this opinion. We think that the will read as a whole indubitably reveals an intention on the part of the testator to dedicate the Thakurdwara to the public and not merely to the members of his family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No male issue recital; committee includes non-relations; no solicitude for heirs; perpetuity requires public beneficiaries.

holdings.text: The user of the temple such as is established by the evidence is more consistent with its being a public endowment.

anchor.surface_text: And in such circumstances, proof of user by the public without interference would be cogent evidence that the dedication was in favour of the public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public worship without interference cogent where initial dedication to idol; distinguished Babu Bhagwan Din.

holdings.text: Prathista takes the place of Uthsarga in dedication of temples and establishes that the dedication was to the public.

anchor.surface_text: But it is also clear from the texts that Prathista takes the place of Uthsarga in dedication of temples, and that there was Prathista of Sri Radhakrishnaji

holdings.reasoning_summary: No Uthsarga (was Prasada utsarga); Prathista substitutes for temples per texts; performed here.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed, the decrees of the courts below are set aside, and a declaration granted that the Thakurdwara is a public temple in which all Hindus have a right to worship.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decrees of the courts below are set aside, and a declaration granted in terms of para 17 a of the plaint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on holding it is public temple; costs from trust properties.
